title: Schoenberg’s Society for Private Musical Performances and Music in Vienna after World War I
description: 4 credits. NP. Group B. Between 1918 and 1922, when it disbanded for financial reasons, Arnold Schoenberg’s Society for Private Musical Performances presented almost three hundred new works by more than forty composers including Bartók, Berg, Busoni, Debussy, Hauer, Mahler, Ravel, Reger, Johann Strauss, Richard Strauss, Stravinsky, Szymanowski, Webern, and, of course, Schoenberg himself. The performers were young singers and instrumentalists from Vienna’s leading musical institutions under the tutelage of Schoenberg, Berg, Webern, and pianist Eduard Steuermann. The repertoire included solo works, chamber music, and chamber arrangements of orchestral pieces prepared by members of the society. In conjunction with the 2017–2018 Yale in New York concert series, this course explores the history and repertoire of the Society. The music in the Yale series, including the Society’s arrangements of Debussy’s Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun, Bruckner’s Seventh Symphony, and some Strauss waltzes, serves as the focal point for discussion. The class explores the social, political, and financial circumstances that prevailed in post-WWI Austria, as well as the convoluted cultural politics of the Viennese musical scene that forced Schoenberg to form his Society. Midterm, final, and short paper required. There are weekly readings, and, wherever possible, performances by participants in the class. If appropriate, some of the papers may become program notes for the Yale in New York series. Participation in the concert programs is not required.
